ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Just virtual lectures
The first part was fully recorded lectures, the second half was non-mandatory in person lecture which was recorded for subsequent later viewings.
recorded lecture for first half, live virtual for second half
N/A
recorded lectures and then live lectures for second half
Recorded lecture
The first half of the semester was a recorded lecture, while the second half was a live virtual lecture.
N/A
Also live zoom lecture
half synchronous
had to look up other resources for better explanations of diagnostic testing results online
Asynchronous lecture for half of the semester.
S&DS 100 only has recorded lectures. S&DS 105 has live virtual lectures.

S&DS 105 followed S&DS 100 UMB. While the first half of the course (S&DS 100) had no live component and was strictly prerecorded (apart from virtual office hours), S&DS 105 involved live lectures. Thus, my model of learning was a mixture of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have gained a stronger understanding of the material taught in the umbrella course and can apply the material in more practical terms. I have also gained more confidence when reading medical papers.
Learned basic statistics as well as useful tools for analyzing medical articles.
A solid introduction to statistics!
Basis statistical literacy, including hypothesis tests, dichotomous tests, confidence intervals, linear regression, probability, etc.
I learned how to read medical papers and a variety of statistical methods associated with medical research.

I already took AP Statistics in high school, but this course solidified my previous understanding in addition to providing me with new statistical medical applications, including relative risk, odds ratios, diagnostic testing (including sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive value, etc.), and other valuable tools for assessing the outcomes of various tests. By reading a weekly paper in the second half of the semester, I was able to apply my knowledge to existing research and modern applications, and I learned to investigate primary literature with a more discerning eye.
Learned basic statistics
basic statistics
I learned how to critically read medical studies and think about the veracity of the statistics presented in them.
Basic introduction to statistics and relevant techniques used to evaluate statistics in medicine.
I developed skills in understanding basic statistical concepts and reading and understanding medical literature within the context of statistical analysis.
Basic statistics + some useful medical stats
quantative analysis a

first half of the course - a lot of basic stats like reading boxplots, hypothesis testing that made me wish i had taken this course sooner in my yale career so that i can understand more of the figures in the academic papers i read for my stem classes; in med stats, learned about diagnostic test result rates and read some med stats related papers which weren't difficult, and not much else
Further comprehension of the material taught in S&DS 100, and an introduction to statistics used in the medical field.

Between S&DS 100 and S&DS 105, I learned concepts such as hypothesis testing, diagnostics testing, confidence intervals, (some) regression, and CLT. I also learned skills such as how to use MINITAB and Microsoft Excel. In S&DS 105, I practiced the skill of reading and understanding scientific journals, specifically medical papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: While the review at the beginning of the course was helpful, it was a bit too slow considering it was reviewing what we just went over in the umbrella course. The course could have been a bit more organized as well.

Strenghts = PSETS for practice
Weakness = lectures, very rushed

Strengths: You have a lot of flexibility to do the work on your own time, and all of the tests were open note.

Weaknesses: The transition from 100 to 105 was kind of weird because 100 was obligatorily asynchronous, whereas 105 had live components. Also, during the first two midterms we were not allowed to ask questions to anyone except the professor.

Strengths: The first half with JRDS was just about perfect. I loved how they had office hours offered pretty much whenever we wanted/needed them. The lectures were clear and concise, and the exams reflected well what we had been taught. I also enjoyed working through the PSETs. This class in general is high value, low effort -- the concepts are fairly simple, but going through them in this manner makes you more scientifically literate. The corny jokes help you remember concepts and are not as annoying as people make them out to be. 
Weaknesses: The second half of the course was poorly taught and poorly structured. It was clear that JRDS and Prof Meyers did not coordinate and plan for a seamless transition beforehand -- we spent the first 5/6 lectures going over concepts that we beat to death in the first half of class. Further, there were a few things that Meyers taught slightly differently from JRDS (for example, different variables were assigned for different statistics in each half of the class) which made things a bit confusing at times. I think the latter half of the course could have greatly benefitted from asynchronous lectures (the synchronous lectures were awkward and incredibly boring), with more clear direction. 

The class is still pretty easy, but if you're a pre-med looking for a stats class take PSYC 200 or S&DS 230 instead. Don't let the "medicine" in the title fool you, the focus on actual medicine is extremely limited in the second half of the course.
I liked how the class was very student-driven and reinforced concepts that we did not know from the previous half of the semester.

This course was split into two sections, the first a general statistics introduction and the second a medical statistics application. The first half of the course was notably stronger in organization and cohesiveness than the second, though both were useful. The first half of the semester presented a large amount of information in a digestible format, and the homework assignments offered direct applications of the material. Lectures were relatively easy to understand, though it may be helpful to remove some nonessential background calculations or information to minimize student overwhelm and/or confusion. The second half of the semester was similar to the first in that it was easy enough to understand with appropriately designed homework assignments. However, I felt that the pace of the second half of the semester was far too slow, and we spent much of our time initially reviewing concepts that we had just covered in the first half of the semester. Therefore, I think that it would be helpful to establish stronger communication between instructors for the first and second half of the semester to minimize unnecessary content overlap. Overall, however, my experience with the course was positive, useful, and readily applicable to my current interests and professional goals.

The recorded lectures in 10x were great - long but they were interesting. The in-person 105 lectures were also good. They had a lot of detail, but sometimes that pace of the course was too slow and it felt like the amount of participation being asked for was artificial and excessive for the class
I feel that I only learned in the first half of the class.

Strengths: nice slow pace allows for thorough learning 
Weakness: could have discussed papers more promptly after reading them when they were fresh on our minds still.

Strengths: The first half of the semester taught by Professor Reuning-Scherer went very smoothly and was enjoyable.
Weaknesses: The second half taught by Professor Meyers was a bit lacking. I appreciated that he asked for our input to revisit topics that we felt needed more explanation after switching into sections, but we had trouble moving on from the review. It seemed that most lectures consisted of 1 hour of review followed by a rushed introduction of a new topic in the last 15 minutes. I appreciate the professor's efforts to ask for student feedback during the semester, but it did not seem like much changed after he received our feedback. Professor Meyers did mention that this was his first time teaching this section, so hopefully, this was just an off experience as he tried to navigate the new course.
The course moved quite slowly but JRDS is great
strengths: organization and clear course content
first half of the course with Jonathan was amazing with recorded lectures and the constant availability of peer tutors.
The strengths were a more comprehensive review of hypothesis tests; however, I would have wanted to review regression more thoroughly.

Ultimately, I would categorize the first half of the course (S&DS 100) as very strong, and the second half of the course (S&DS 105) as very weak. This is ultimately a reflection of the two different professors who taught throughout the fall semester (JDRS for 100; Meyers for 105). While S&DS 100 had no live component, there were ample, ample opportunities to attend office hours with the instructor or teaching assistants. The prerecorded lectures were also very engaging due to JDRS's humor and passionate personality. On the other hand, S&DS 105 involved a live lecture, but I did not find it as engaging. Often, Meyers encouraged students to respond through the chat option to answer practice problems. While this enabled some interaction, I believe it would have been more effective to hold small breakout rooms so that students could collaborate more actively with peers. However I thought that the discussion of medical journal entries within breakout rooms was a strength of S&DS 105, as it enabled students to verbally collaborate with peers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live lectures helped with engagement but were slightly rushed

Succeeded: flexibility with regard to students' schedules, we could complete most of the work on our own time

Weaknesses: There was basically no engagement in the first part of the course, but I think during normal semesters this is what usually happens since intro stats starts off as a huge lecture.

Asynchronous lectures and ample office hours in the first half were great. Synchronous zoom lectures are just terrible in general, but one's that try to get students to respond to questions (like these) are simply painful.

The course employed synchronous and asynchronous lecture components throughout the semester, and I find that both were suited to remote learning. Quizzes and tests were also designed well, and I did not encounter any problems during testing periods. However, the final exam was offered on a Microsoft Word document rather than Canvas, and the change in formatting (plus the requirement that we show all calculations) made for increased technical difficulty. The format of the test itself would have been more manageable if we were given more time for the final exam. The first two exams of the course allowed students 3 hours, and the final exam allowed only 2.5 hours; providing equal amounts of time for all tests would be helpful.
Would be good to do some more practice problems/scenarios in class, but overall the format was great. The papers were generally interesting and the lectures were well-constructed.
recorded lectures were effective. reading papers in the second half did not teach me anything

Succeeded: class discussion on papers went well when we had a google form with questions to refer to. 
Improvement: more class discussion in lecture as opposed to writing everything in the chat.

The quizzes, homework, and pre-recorded lectures in the first half were wonderful and conducive to learning. The switch to asynchronous lectures for the Medicine section felt unnecessary as lectures were not engaging. We did participate in break-out room paper discussions, but the assigned discussion questions were not conducive to productive conversation.
Online live virtual lectures were great!!
It was well suited I liked the recorded lectures
Both recorded lectures and live zooms were effective.
online instruction and support

asynchronous lectures and having lots of office hours, plus lots of time to plan out when to take the midterm exams, worked. synchronous lectures and synchronous exam time did not work - added unnecessary stress to students, and although lectures were uploaded later they did not contain transcripts which made them a bit difficult to follow (please increase accessibility by providing even automated transcripts, thank you)
The recorded lectures for S&DS 100 could have been more engaging.

While S&DS 100 had no live component, there were ample, ample opportunities with the instructor or teaching assistants and to discuss work with peers during office hours. A live lecture component was then introduced through S&DS 105; however, I did not find the engagement strategies of S&DS 105 to be effective. While Meyers attempted to keep the course engaging by taking advantage of the chat tool in Zoom, I felt that the class's my reliance on the chat box rather than verbal questioning caused us (or at least me) to become disengaged. Personally, I believe that it would have been more helpful to actively solve practice problems in small peer groups within breakout rooms instead of using the chat option, as the chat often became biased according to what the first few students wrote. (When using a chat option, it is easy for students to simply submit the same answer as those who answered the question first, and in doing so, they miss out on true collaboration.) However, I did enjoy breakout sessions while discussing papers, as these sessions enabled students to verbally collaborate with peers in the way I was hoping for.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if needed for major or interested in statistical analysis
Yes! it's a pretty cool class.

If you're pre-med, I'd recommend taking a different stats course to fulfill the requirement. This one isn't awful and is fairly easy, but there are better courses offered. The "medical" focus of the second half of the class is extremely limited.

I would recommend this course to anybody interested in practicing medicine. I have a much better understanding about how diagnostic testing works, and I think this course has lots of real-world implications.

I would recommend this course to a student only if the student foresees a need for statistics in his/her/their future education or career. If only a basic understanding of statistics is required, it may be more time-efficient to read through a statistics book to understand the main concepts versus spending an entire semester on the material. That being said, I find statistics rather interesting, and I enjoyed learning the new material, so it depends on how important statistics will be in one's future.
Yes, you're probably taking because you need to, but it's a good course.
no, I would recommend a different section line 101-104
Yes, I would recommend this course to any pre-med student who still needs a math class

I would recommend the SDS 10X portion of the course (first half taught by Professor Reuning-Schere), but I cannot say that I would recommend the Medicine section (taught by Professor Meyers). I recognize that this was Professor Meyer's first time teaching the course and I greatly appreciate his efforts to receive student feedback but my overall experience with the section was disappointing.
Yes!! Great intro statistics class for students interested in medicine
This is a req for NSCI, so you have to take if you are doing for that. Otherwise, not really.
yes

DO NOT TAKE MED STATS. Even if you're pre-med, just stick with Jonathan's section the whole way through so you don't have to switch learning methods after two exams and especially for the final exam. Med Stats is funky because the professor insisted on synchronous lectures and a proctored exam on Zoom via a Word document where it was quite unpredictable on how to best prepare for it, as it was nothing like the psets. The only "med" part of "med stats" was learning about diagnostic test results and reading med stats papers, but that's something you can teach yourself if you're really interested. Stick with Jonathan to actually get through ANOVA and other stats topics as he's a great teacher with a lot of experience!
I would if they were specifically interested in medicine, but not for any other general interest in statistics.

While I would recommend S&DS 100 UMB to another student, I would not recommend S&DS 105 for the second half of the course. I took S&DS 105 because it was recommended for pre-med students, yet I believe that I would have learned far more concepts applicable to medicine in S&DS 103: Introduction to Statistics: Social Sciences. Whereas the piazza for S&DS 100 UMB suggests that students in S&DS 103 were tested on ANOVA concepts, we did not begin learning ANOVA until the very last lecture. While S&DS 100 was engaging and insightful, S&DS 105 involved far too much review and not enough new material, thus rendering it flat and underwhelming.

extras.title:
S&DS 505 01/S&DS 105 01
        Intro to Stat: Medicine/Intro to Statistics: Medicine
